content.description:
I sat under the shade of the tree below

Sweeney's Special

after soloing

Easy To Remember

, and I just sat there in a daze thinking about the people in my life that I have lost. I just looked up at the steep, beautiful, colorful arÃªte that shot straight up in the sky. It was like looking at a pathway to heaven. I was sitting in the great hall of Odin (a great legendary god). I felt the presence of late, great climbing partner Jimmy Forester and my late nephew who grew as a climber and person before being taken from us. Both of them fought the great battle of life. As I sat there, I could see holds to start appearing. I asked a good friend Matt King to help me put this route up. I wanted to put it up ground up, but it was so steep and nothing to hook. So I rapped in only to realize that after a short rappel I was out in space. So I heel hooked and basically downclimbed/ rappelled in to install each bolt. After ab crushing and bicep pumping work, we had all the bolts in except 1 at the start of the traverse. Matt tried to pull me in but no way. We had to climb

Sweeney's Special

, and I tensioned way out left to install the last bolt as to make sure it did not take away the

Sweeney's Special

adventure. 6 tries later each with a biceps and forearm pumping attempt we have Valhalla: where warriors who die as heroes and legends in battle dwell eternally. Thanks, Matt, for the work and support.
content.protection:
Gear for

Easy To Remember

or

Texas Sucks

then gear for

Sweeney's Special

and then 5 draws to the top. There is a chain anchor.
content.location:
It is above

Easy To Remember

. Either start from the ground for the full adventure or climb up to the tree above

Easy To Remember

. Climb

Sweeney's Special

before making the mantel. Bust out left to the first bolt. Use long draws for the first two bolts on the traverse.

Rap the routes. We worked the route from the tree and when lowered down the belayer would throw out some slack to pull you in.

content.description:
Move to the right hand side of the belay ledge at the top of

Texas Sucks

/

Easy to Remember

and climb the left most crack to the large ledge at the top.
content.location:
Left hand side of the Apple Cider area.  Starts at the

Texas Sucks

/

Easy to Remember

belay ledge.

content.description:
Climb the handcrack up into the right-facing corner. Continue up the corner almost to its top, traverse right around a prow and downclimb a short crack to a bolted anchor at a nice ledge.

It is possible to add a second pitch. The nice, steep, twin cracks are

Sweeney's Special

. The colorful arete to the left is

Valhalla

. To the right are

Ticket To New Zealand

,

Birthday Crack

, and

Easy To Remember

(P2).
content.protection: Standard East Animas rack with extra hand-sized pieces.
content.location:
This route starts at a handcrack just to the right of a right-facing corner. It is on the left side of the

Apple Cider

area.

content.description:
This is actually the second pitch that can be done after

Easy To Remember

or

Texas Sucks

.  The route climbs one or both of the short, overhanging, finger cracks and continues to the top of the cliff.
content.location:
Start at the top of either

Texas Sucks

or

Easy To Remember

.

content.description:
After you pull the tricky and deceptive move into

Sweeney's

chimney, stem for a few feet, and reach out climber's left to the first bolt of a 4 bolt route that climbs the left independent, steep, and exposed adjacent face to

Sweeney's

chimney. This route climbs back to the original anchor of

Sweeney's Special

.

A 60m rope will get you to the ground from the anchors.
content.protection: 4 quickdraws plus gear for the routes you choose to access this final pitch.
content.location:
This route can be either approached by

Easy To Remember

or

Texas Sucks

or

Sweeney's Direct

.

content.description:
This is the easiest route leading to the top of the

Apple Cider

area and I think is most often done as an approach to

The Overview

. It starts up a crack that leads to a right-angling ramp feature. From the top of the ramp, move into a left-facing corner, and take it to the top.
content.location:
It is on the right side of the Apple Cider area, just to the right of

Punta Magna

.

content.description:
This route is located on the upper face of Apple Cider. Climb

Heroes are Hard to Find

to a large ledge. Sky Slab takes four bolts up an arete to an anchor underneath Riders on the Storm.

The crux comes right away at the first bolt. I stemmed across the crack - it would be contrived not to, but perhaps it is better to avoid this. The move has been done without the stem. The crux is around V6/7, and the rest is enjoyable 12a. Better beta could cut the grade conceivably.

It has interesting moves, but it is kind of a pain to get to, so I rate it only 2 stars.
content.location:
It is above

Heroes are Hard to Find

and below Riders on the Storm. This is protected by four bolts with a two bolt anchor (lowering biners) and a one bolt belay anchor on the ledge to start. There is gear to be had at the lower anchor if one bolt isn't enough, but you are on a huge ledge, and the first bolt is easy to clip. You can rap to the ground with a 70m comfortably.

content.description: This route climbs about 15' of dirty unprotected face climbing before getting into the dihedral.  The crux comes on the first pitch near the top with thin gear (small cams work well) and strenuous moves over a bulge.
content.protection: Bring small cams for the crux (black and blue Aliens).
content.location:
This route starts just right of the large flake for

Apple Cider

.  Climb up a large, left-facing dihedral.

content.description: This is a great new route, taking a nice line to the top of the cliff. Bouldery start and continuous techy moves characterize the first pitch. This route pushes the mind a little after the second bolt then turns more moderate for the second pitch.  Can be done in one pitch.
content.protection: The first pitch is all bolts.  The second takes some gear with a few bolts.
content.location:
This lies right of

Apple Cider

and crosses

Tennis Shoe Traverse

.  Face climb following seams to a shallow corner and a belay station.  The second half follows the shallow corner which becomes a roof and crack system which is followed to the top. Descend from fixed anchor (70m rope).

content.description: This was bolted by Marcus Garcia and Gentle Ben Griffin (thanks for lettin' me sleez yer route). This route was named after local soft man, JJ Nockjob. Bouldery and fun climbing for the first 4 boltz leadz to easier climbing in the crack above.
content.protection: 6 boltz including the anchors and a few small nuts and cams for the crack section. We did leave some draws at the anchors for your enjoyment.
content.location:
This gangsta-ass line starts 6 feet to the right of

Pandora

. It goes straight up for the first 2 boltz and than veers hard right (much like my ...) to an undercling jug below the third bolt. After that, follow the crack to the anchors.

content.description: The route start just as you come out of the cave.  Look up right for the first bolt at the lip. The crux is an intense series of moves from the first bolt to the second bolt.  You can stick clip the second bolt if you need. The route finishes off with a matrix of bouldery moves with good rest between them. The last move at the anchor can be a heart breaker. Chris Barlow got the second ascent after me in. We both agree with the rating. You can bypass the crux and climb 5.12 if you use the tree behind you.

This is a good route that has some interesting moves and some stances to place protection. The start can be a little sandy, but quickly improves. Ends at a bolted anchor at a ledge.

Eds. there is a very large, loose flake on this route.  Beware!
content.location:
The route starts around the corner a little left of

Apple Cider

.

content.description: Start with a low overhang to gain a crack system. Follow the crack system to a roof, move left and continue up cracks to the top of the wall.
content.location:
This is on the right side of the

Apple Cider

area.

content.description: Go up the stemming dihedrals. Belay under an oak shade tree.
content.location:
This is to the right of the cave with

The Slaves

and Texas Sucks.

content.description:
Directions feels like moving on European limestone but softer, more textured, and much more sensitive to your attitudes and emotions. From the

Pandora

P1 anchor ledge, enter a sustained boulder problem that leads to a jug. Shake out until you're ready to enjoy the quality crux sequences of

The Corrections

.
content.protection:
12 bolts total including the

Pandora

P1 anchor.
content.location:
This is basically a direct start to

The Corrections

Start by doing P1 of

Pandora

. From the ledge, go straight up (left of

Pandora's

P2) clipping 2 new bolts leading to the fixed cable draw that protects

The Corrections

crux. Continue through all the business of the

Corrections

.

climbs.name: Direct to Sweeney's
climbs.fa: Ben Kiessel/Bill Grasse.  FFA: Ben K.

content.description:
This is a line just to the left of the old [gear] route: "We Don't Need Another Hero." We have been looking at it for a while, so we put it up.

Fun face climbing leads to a couple of large moves right, then finishing on some tricky moves to catch

Texas Sucks

. Finish on the top moves of

Texas Sucks

, and if psyched, take it into

Sweeney's

for a full value 5.12 pitch!

We put this up as an option to connect to Sweeney's, but you can choose a number of different options after the bolts.

06/11/2021: Ben added two bolts to this making it less run out. You will still want to place gear in some sections and for the top. See his comment below.
content.protection: A single set from 0.2 to #1 Camalot ought to do. Bring runners and five draws.
content.location:
It is 15' right of

Texas Sucks

.

climbs.name: Crimpin' and Pimpin'
climbs.fa: Bolted on lead by: Marcus Garcia. FFA: Marcus Garcia

content.description:
The route starts directly left of

Contortionist

and directly right of

Chingadero

.

Start on huge hand features, to a look friendly, but not so friendly mantle. Then grab the secret crimp. Stand on the ledge that you mantled on and shake out like a motha effin' Pimp. Now that you're big pimpin', start the crimpin' onto the boulder problem slab. If you pull the slab, you're probably feeling strong in your muscles, but now it's time to exercise your brain all the way to the chains.  This is really fun on good East Animas rock.
content.location: Its between Contortionist and Chingadero.

content.description:
Like Jonathan Franzen's book by the same name, The Corrections is all about fixing old problems. In this climb's case, the culmination is one of Durango's best and, as of this time, hardest established routes.

The line was aided many years ago; the first ascentionist left only a few studs and a bashie as evidence of his passage. After a reconnaissance on aid, Marcus re-envisioned this line as a free climb and began work. A month later, we had The Corrections.

Begin by climbing Punta Magna through the finger crack bulge. From the stem below Punta Magna's crux, head right along a ramp to a bolt near the arete. Continue up and right with pumpy moves along a slopy rail to a vicious sequence to get into the dihedral. Continue up the dihedral and clip the anchor on the ledge above.
content.protection:
Gear from tiny to 1.5" for the first part of

Punta Magna

then 8 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

Due to the traverse out of the corner and around the arete from

Punta Magna

, one must either use double-rope technique or implement many very long slings and back clean for the gear in the corner.
content.location:
Begin as for

Punta Magna

, but climb right along the ramp about 40 feet up.

content.description:
Start the same as for

Green Puke

, and a little over halfway up move right under a roof, and then continue up cracks to the top.
content.location:
This is on the right hand side of the

Apple Cider

area.  Start the same as

Green Puke

.

content.description:
Climb steep moves off the ground, then pull the awkward/bouldery crux (gear is available but difficult to place), and climb the finger crack that leads into

Apple Cider's

first pitch. Finish at same bolted anchor.
content.location:
The route starts to the left of

Apple Cider

.

content.description: A hard thin start leads to thin boulder problems up higher.
content.location:
This is just left of the

Contortionist

.

climbs.name: Charlie's Indirect (submitted as Travels With Charlie)

content.description:
P1 - start the same as

Easy to Remember

, then go up a right-angling ramp past a ledge to a belay behind a large boulder.

P1 Variation - do a more direct finger crack start that meets up with the right-angling ramp (5.9).

P2 - traverses to the left on a sloping ledge and moves around a corner.

Per

Michael Borga

: the line shown and listed here is what we called "Charlie's Indirect!"

"Travels with Charlie" went straight up and over the boulder where the first belay station is achieved. We called the p1 variation in the description "Charlie's Direct".
content.location:
The start is the same as that of

Easy To Remember

.  To the right of

Texas Sucks

and left of

Apple Cider

.

content.description:
This is a second pitch to

Texas Sucks

or

Easy to Remember

. Start off the right side of the belay ledge and climb the pretty good crack (hands - fingers) to a bolted anchor on a large ledge at the top.
content.location:
This is on the left hand side of the

Apple Cider

area. Start by climbing

Texas Sucks

or

Easy to Remember

as a first pitch.

content.description:
P1. Start up a large, right-facing flake, and climb to below a roof. Move up and right past the roof to gain another crack. Follow this to a chimney which leads to a ledge on the left and a bolted anchor.

P2. Climb up broken rock to the top of a boulder/flake, step across to the crack and take it to another bolted anchor at the top.

Descent: two rappels will get you back on the ground. Watch the rope pull after the first rappel, there is some loose stuff that could come down.
content.location:
This route starts just left of the obvious corner of

Punta Magna

.

content.description:
This is an obvious hand crack through an overhanging wall on the left side of

Apple Cider

Wall.  The crux comes about halfway up at a bulge.  It is a little dirty, but it is still a very good route.
content.protection: Cams up to 3", some larger sizes could be useful.
content.location:
This is on the left side of

Apple Cider

Wall with large rocks at the base. Originally, the tree with slings around it at the top was used for an anchor and descent.

Per

Ben Kiessel

: there is now a two bolt anchor with chains and Mussy hooks at the top.

content.description:
3AM Handy is a route inspired by my girlfriend and Valentine's Day. It ascends the face and prow directly to the left and 1/3 of the way up

Apple Cider

.

There are four ways to start this route. I will describe in more detail what will likely be the most common way to do the route.

Climb the flake up into the small cave on Apple Cider, and place a piece with a runner. Pull out and over the small cave, and head towards the finger crack on the left. Place your 3" piece firmly in the wider crack to keep the rope running smooth. You should be getting nice and warmed up now.

Head left, placing another piece in the finger crack, towards the first bolt. Pull some delicate and balancy moves to get the blood flowing.

Clip the first draw with a runner. Follow the path of least resistance, curving slightly out left and then back in. They do this sometimes. Continue following the bolts to the top. There are a few good spots to rest and take it nice and slow on the way up.

The crux cums as you near the tip of the prow. Find yourself in a very exposed position as you pull over the last bulge and bust it out left to finish on the nice big ledge.

Note: this route can also be done by starting on The

Contortionist

,

Crimpin' and Pimpin'

, or

Chingadero

.
content.protection:
If doing the

Apple Cider

start, I suggest, in BD C4 sizes, a 0.3, 3, 0.4, all with runners. From there, use 1 runner on the first bolt and 6 more quickdraws to the top.

A 60m rope works just fine.

If linking in from one of the other sport routes, bring draws for that route and a single or double length runner for the anchor plus 5 or 6 more draws to the top.
content.location:
This is in the

Apple Cider

area.

Either start on

Apple Cider

or one of those hard AF sporto routes to the left.
